item.title: Clementine add a quote by Aldous Huxley
item.description:
"The Savage interrupted him. "But isn't it natural to feel there's a God?"
"You might as well ask if it's natural to do up one's trousers with zippers," said the Controller sarcastically. "You remind me of another of those old fellows called Bradley. He defined philosophy as the finding of bad reason for what one believes by instinct. As if one believed anything by instinct! One believes things because one has been conditioned to believe them. Finding bad reasons for what one believes for other bad reasonsâ€“that's philosophy. People believe in God because they've been conditioned to." -- Aldous Huxley

item.title: Clementine add a quote by Anais Nin
item.description: "We write to taste life twice, in the moment and in retrospect." -- Anais Nin

item.title: Clementine add a quote by Anais Nin
item.description: "And the day came when the risk to remain tight in a bud was more painful than the risk it took to blossom." -- Anais Nin

item.title: Clementine add a quote by Percy Bysshe Shelley
item.description: "Our sweetest songs are those of saddest thought." -- Percy Bysshe Shelley

item.title: Clementine add a quote by Percy Bysshe Shelley
item.description: "Soul meets soul on lovers lips." -- Percy Bysshe Shelley

item.title: Clementine add a quote by Percy Bysshe Shelley
item.description: "The pleasure that is in sorrow is sweeter than the pleasure of pleasure itself." -- Percy Bysshe Shelley

item.title: Clementine add a quote by Percy Bysshe Shelley
item.description: "The more we study, the more we discover our ignorance" -- Percy Bysshe Shelley

item.title: Clementine add a quote by Virginia Woolf
item.description: "Nothing thicker than a knife's blade separates happiness from melancholy." -- Virginia Woolf

item.title: Clementine add a quote by Virginia Woolf
item.description: "Love, the poet said, is woman's whole existence." -- Virginia Woolf

item.title: Clementine add a quote by Virginia Woolf
item.description: "Anyone who has the temerity to write about Jane Austen is aware of [two] facts: first, that of all great writers she is the most difficult to catch in the act of greatness; second, that there are twenty-five elderly gentlemen living in the neighbourhood of London who resent any slight upon her genius as if it were an insult to the chastity of their aunts." -- Virginia Woolf

item.title: Clementine add a quote by Virginia Woolf
item.description: "Never let anybody guess that you have a mind of your own. Above all be pure" -- Virginia Woolf

item.title: Clementine add a quote by Virginia Woolf
item.description: "He smiled the most exquisite smile, veiled by memory, tinged by dreams." -- Virginia Woolf
